DOC.brief_summary: To demonstrate that a focused Emergency Department (ED) intervention for uncontrolled hyperglycemia enables safe and effective glycemic management and reduces emergency room re-visits. We assessed hypoglycemia BG < 60mg/dL; change in mean blood glucose and A1C, and ED revisits for hyperglycemia.
DOC.brief_title: Stop Emergency Room Visits for Hyperglycemia Project - District of Columbia (DC)
DOC.detailed_description: Patients with BG > 200mg/dL presenting to an urban tertiary care hospital ED were enrolled in a 4 week prospective intervention with historic self-controls. Subjects returned at 12-72 hours, 2 and 4 weeks. Diabetes medications (including sulfonylureas, metformin and/or insulin) were initiated and/or adjusted at each visit using the intervention algorithm per presenting blood glucose and prior diabetes medications. Survival skills self-management education and navigation to outpatient services were provided.
DOC.criteria: Age > 18 years Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus, random BG > 200 mg/dL, willing and able to provide informed consent and to participate in diabetes selfmanagement education (DSME) stable for discharge from the ED once hyperglycemia treatment initiated. type 1 Diabetes Mellitus, diabetic ketoacidosis or hyperosmolar nonketotic state, concomitant treatment with glucocorticoids (other than stable maintenance dose therapy), cognitive or physical impairment preventing participation in DSME unwillingness or inability to provide consent and/or attend followup visits.
